entry.title: MtnFly Simulations freeware Learjet-35A progress Update
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. MtnFly Simulations have been developing a freeware Learjet-25A and have recently released a substantial progress update, outlining what has to be done, what is complete and even showcasing a full flight of the aircraft on their youtube channel.Â Their update log outlining what has been done is as follows:Â - NAV and COM radios are fully functional and will now work with the Garmin GPS even though there is no concept of a true standby frequency in the early model 35's radios. - The yaw damper has been modelled and is now functioning. - The three AC to DC power inverters are now modelled and functioning. - The FC-200 autopilot is now working as expected. - Improvements have been made to the side audio panels. - All four batteries are now connected to their respective power busses and functionÂ - The captain's flight instruments are close to being fully functional. - The emergency brake lever has been modelled and now functions. - The cabin temperature indicator will now display a "cold-soaked" temperature on start-up. It will react to the user's set temperature setting once the engines are running and the passenger air conditioning system is turned on. - Improvements have been made to tying electrical circuits to their respective circuit breakers. - The RCA WXD weather radar has been modelled for those that prefer to fly "old school" without any GPS. - Panel lighting has been added. - Exterior Lighting has been added. - There have been many improvements to emissive lighting throughout the aircraft. - The wing to fuselage fairing has been added. - There have been numerous modelling updates. â At Threshold we will keep you updated while this project progresses.

entry.title: Flight Simulation Association Publishes Travel Details on FlightSimExpo 2023
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Earlier this week, Flight Simulation Association published the travel details for FlightSimExpo 2023. The 3-day event is currently set to take place between June 23 - 25 in the city of Houston. Different from previous expos, FlightSImExpo 2023 will be held in two different locations. On Friday the 23rd, the event will be hosted in DoubleTree Houston Hobby where guests can participate in a reception and welcome seminars. On Saturday and Sunday, the event will move to Lone Star Flight Museum which is around a 15 minutes drive away from the hotel. Those who attend the event will receive free access to the museum for the weekend. Apart from the official events, the organizers are also working with NASA, the FAA, and other parties to arrange off-site excursions. The organizers have once again negotiated discounted prices at two hotels for attendees for FlightSimExpo. They encourage anyone who wishes to attend the event to book their hotel rooms as soon as possible in order to enjoy a special rate of $109/night at the DoubleTree and $89/night at Houston Marriott South at Hobby Airport. Guests at these two hotels will enjoy free transportation to/from Houston Hobby Airport, as well as free parking for those who are driving. Finally, the organizers have also obtained a 10% discount for those looking to purchase tickets to Houston from Delta or Southwest Airlines. More details on travel discounts can be found here. Registration for the expo will open in December; a 3-day pass can be purchased for only $50 USD. Currently, a final list of developers who will participate in the event has not been released; Threshold will keep you updated on this front. â

entry.title: Fenix Simulations Releases New A320 Hotfix
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Fenix Simulations has just released a new hotfix to their recent A320 update, addressing issues with the rudders and landing behavior (it was prone to bouncing even with smooth touchdowns, introduced with the first hotfix that addressed the drag coefficient of the flaps). The update is available on their website for registered customers. â â A320 v1.0.3.134 [SYSTEM] Â - Adjusted custom low speed friction model to be slightly more fluidÂ - Fixed incorrect air/ground mix factor causing irrecoverable nose down elevator after a bounced landingÂ - Removed alpha-buffer pseudo-prot, causing issues with flare authority in certain conditions [FM]Â - Adjusted spoiler efficacyÂ - Improved suspension geometry and setup to reduce bouncing, absorbing more energy on touchdown and subsequently sitting lower on the groundÂ - Added lift dumping to spoilers so the aircraft is more stable after touchdown in a crosswindÂ - Improved aircraft's crosswind and weathervaning characteristics Â - Adjusted lateral tyre friction to prevent weight on wheels sideslip and/or unintended ice skating â Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: Cockspur C510 Mustang Released
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. MSFS aircraft developers Cockspur have released their all-new C510 Mustang for Microsoft Flight Simulator. This release may come as a surprise to some in the community who have not been following development too closely, as initially it was due to release a little further down the road. The C510 is a very light business jet developed and built by the Cessna aircraft company. The mustang is approved for single pilot operations and seats 4 passengers in the standard configuration. It is also used by various operators throughout the world as an air-ambulance which has been recreated by the Cockspur team! The aircraft offers the following features; -3 different variants; Standard, High Sierra, and air ambulance -Multiple liveries -Different static elements depending on variant -Accurate flight model -Accurate systems modelling -Built from scratch for MSFS -Interactive Cabin -Visible passengers -Custom engine sounds -Extensive documentation -Developed with help from real Mustang Pilots -G1000 NXi integration The Cockspur C510 can be purchased from the Cockspur website for Euro 24.99 â
